title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement [INSERT CONTACT METHOD]. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Benchmarks
text: short vignette, show benchmarks zoomerjoin package, comparing excellent fuzzyjoin package. two packages designed different things - fuzzyjoin package fast, provides distance functions (well joining modes) - ’s useful comparison shows time can saved using LSH relative pairwise comparisons, long okay using Jaccard similarity. future, hoping expand package implement LSH method edit distance, add benchmarks / feature completed.

title: Benchmarks
text: , show time takes fuzzyjoin zoomerjoin fuzzily join two datasets size dataset increases. Fuzzyjoin initially quick, runtime scales square input size. Zoomerjoin slower small datasets less memory-intensive, scales sum rows dataset, becomes quicker larger datasets.

title: A Zoomerjoin Guided Tour
text: vignette gives basic overview core functionality zoomerjoin package. Zoomerjoin empowers fuzzily-match datasets millions rows seconds, staying light memory usage. makes feasible perform fuzzy-joins datasets hundreds millions observations matter minutes. added feature, package also provides wrapper fast 2-dimensional spatial joins using rust kdtree crate.

title: A Zoomerjoin Guided Tour
text: Zoomerjoin’s blazingly fast joins made possible optimized, performant implimentation MinHash algorithm written Rust. conventional joining packages compare pairs records two datasets wish join, MinHash algorithm manages compare similar records . results matches orders magnitudes faster matching software packages: zoomerjoin takes hours minutes join datasets taken centuries join using matching methods.

title: A Zoomerjoin Guided Tour
text: ’re familiar logical-join syntax dplyr, already know use fuzzy join join two datasets. Zoomerjoin provides lsh_inner_join lsh_full_join (among others), fuzzy-joining analogues corresponding dplyr functions. demonstrate syntax using package join corpuses, formed entries Database Ideology, Money Politics, Elections (DIME) (Bonica 2016). first corpus looks follows: second looks follows: two Corpuses can’t directly joined misspellings. means must use fuzzy-matching capabilities zoomerjoin: , provide short description arguments. first two arguments, , b, direct analogues dplyr arguments, two data frames want join. field also acts ‘dplyr’ (provides function columns want match ). n_gram_width parameter determines wide n-grams used similarity evaluation , threshold argument determines similar pair strings (Jaccard similarity) considered match. Users stringdist fuzzyjoin package familiar arguments, bear mind packages measure string distance (distance 0 indicates complete similarity), package operates string similarity, threshold .8 keep matches 80% Jaccard similarity. n_bands band_width parameters govern performance LSH. default parameters perform well medium-size (n < 10^7) datasets matches somewhat similar (similarity > .8), may require tuning settings. lsh_hyper_grid_search function can help select parameters given properties LSH desire. details, textreuse package excellent vignette, zoomerjoin provides re-implimentation profiling tools, lsh_probability, lsh_bandwidth (although implementations differ slightly hyperparameters package different).
code: corpus_1 ## # A tibble: 500,000 × 2 ##        a field                                                                   ##    <dbl> <chr>                                                                   ##  1     1 ufwa cope committee                                                     ##  2     2 committee to re elect charles e. bennett                                ##  3     3 montana democratic party non federal account                            ##  4     4 mississippi power & light company management political action and educ… ##  5     5 napus pac for postmasters                                               ##  6     6 aminoil good government fund                                            ##  7     7 national women's political caucus of california                         ##  8     8 minnesota gun owners' political victory fund                            ##  9     9 metropolitan detroit afl cio cope committee                             ## 10    10 carpenters legislative improvement committee united brotherhood of car… ## # ℹ 499,990 more rows corpus_2 ## # A tibble: 500,000 × 2 ##         b field                                ##     <dbl> <chr>                                ##  1 832471 avrp studios inc                     ##  2 832472 avrd design                          ##  3 832473 avenales cattle co                   ##  4 832474 auto dealers of michigan political a ##  5 832475 atty & counselor at law              ##  6 832476 at&t united way                      ##  7 832477 ashland food & liquors               ##  8 832478 arvance turkey ranch inc             ##  9 832479 arizona federation of teachers       ## 10 832480 arianas restaurant                   ## # ℹ 499,990 more rows start_time <- Sys.time() join_out <- lsh_inner_join(corpus_1, corpus_2,                            by = "field", n_gram_width=6,                            n_bands=20, band_width=6, threshold = .8) print(Sys.time() - start_time) ## Time difference of 27.92772 secs print(join_out) ## # A tibble: 47,840 × 4 ##         a field.x                                                      b field.y ##     <dbl> <chr>                                                    <dbl> <chr>   ##  1 295772 business resource consultants                           1.11e6 busine… ##  2 114066 izard county democratic central cmte                    1.05e6 seward… ##  3  62821 texas apartment association pac account,                8.59e5 texas … ##  4  68851 international brotherhood of electrical workers local … 9.60e5 intern… ##  5 110117 laco mechanical services                                1.13e6 laco m… ##  6  50439 political action for classified employees of californi… 8.73e5 politi… ##  7 305274 k & l distributing co                                   1.28e6 k & l … ##  8 167091 service employees local 79                              1.21e6 servic… ##  9 221484 toll road investors partnership                         1.01e6 toll r… ## 10 463447 service employees local 362                             1.21e6 servic… ## # ℹ 47,830 more rows

title: A Zoomerjoin Guided Tour
text: Bonica, Adam. 2016. Database Ideology, Money Politics, Elections: Public version 2.0 [Computer file]. Stanford, CA: Stanford University Libraries.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Beniamino Green. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Green B (2023). zoomerjoin: Insanely fast fuzzy joins. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://beniaminogreen.github.io/zoomerjoin/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {zoomerjoin: Insanely fast fuzzy joins},   author = {Beniamino Green},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://beniaminogreen.github.io/zoomerjoin/}, }

title: Insanely fast fuzzy joins
text: zoomerjoin R package empowers fuzzy-join massive datasets rapidly, little memory consumption. backbone high-performance implementation MinHash, algorithm shortcuts expensive computational step comparing possible pairings records two datasets. practice, means zoomerjoin can fuzzily-join datasets days, even years faster matching packages. zoomerjoin used -production join datasets hundreds millions names hours. package also wraps kdtree Rust crate provide blazingly fast spatial joins.

title: Insanely fast fuzzy joins
text: must Rust installed compile package. package compiled, Rust longer required, can safely uninstalled. install Rust windows, can use Rust installation wizard, found . Linux MacOs, can install Rust :
code: curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh

title: Insanely fast fuzzy joins
text: rust installed Rust, able install package install_github function devtools package:
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("beniaminogreen/zoomerjoin")

title: Insanely fast fuzzy joins
text: Load package typing
code: library(zoomerjoin)

title: Insanely fast fuzzy joins
text: flagship feature zoomerjoins lsh_join family functions, designed near drop-ins corresponding dplyr/fuzzyjoin commands: lsh_left_join() lsh_right_join() lsh_inner_join() lsh_full_join() ’s snippet showing use lhs_inner_join() merge two datasets political donors Database Ideology, Money Politics, Elections (DIME). can see detailed example vignette introductory vignette. start two corpuses like combine, corpus_1: corpus_2: corpuses observation ID column, donor name column. like join two datasets donor names column, two can’t directly joined misspellings. , use lsh_inner_join function fuzzily join two donor name column. ZoomerJoin finds joins matching rows just seconds.
code: corpus_1 ## # A tibble: 500,000 × 2 ##        a field                                                                   ##    <dbl> <chr>                                                                   ##  1     1 ufwa cope committee                                                     ##  2     2 committee to re elect charles e. bennett                                ##  3     3 montana democratic party non federal account                            ##  4     4 mississippi power & light company management political action and educ… ##  5     5 napus pac for postmasters                                               ##  6     6 aminoil good government fund                                            ##  7     7 national women's political caucus of california                         ##  8     8 minnesota gun owners' political victory fund                            ##  9     9 metropolitan detroit afl cio cope committee                             ## 10    10 carpenters legislative improvement committee united brotherhood of car… ## # … with 499,990 more rows corpus_2 ## # A tibble: 500,000 × 2 ##         b field                                ##     <dbl> <chr>                                ##  1 832471 avrp studios inc                     ##  2 832472 avrd design                          ##  3 832473 avenales cattle co                   ##  4 832474 auto dealers of michigan political a ##  5 832475 atty & counselor at law              ##  6 832476 at&t united way                      ##  7 832477 ashland food & liquors               ##  8 832478 arvance turkey ranch inc             ##  9 832479 arizona federation of teachers       ## 10 832480 arianas restaurant                   ## # … with 499,990 more rows start_time <- Sys.time() join_out <- lsh_inner_join(corpus_1, corpus_2, n_gram_width=6, n_bands=20, band_width=6) ## Joining by 'field' print(Sys.time() - start_time) ## Time difference of 9.807082 secs print(join_out) ## # A tibble: 178,130 × 4 ##         a field.x                                                      b field.y ##     <dbl> <chr>                                                    <dbl> <chr>   ##  1 330353 gm transportation inc                                   1.27e6 ksea t… ##  2 319593 iowa association of realtors                            1.10e6 or ass… ##  3 143116 joaquin castro for state representative                 9.58e5 joaqui… ##  4  63678 los angeles turf club and its affiliated entity, pacif… 9.51e5 los an… ##  5  61672 faculty for our university s future, a committee spons… 8.82e5 facult… ##  6   7712 boise county republican central cmte                    1.20e6 sonoma… ##  7 363965 mlg family limited partnership                          9.07e5 lrc fa… ##  8  88701 sac county republican party                             1.26e6 luna c… ##  9 174972 north dakota republicans district 17                    1.10e6 north … ## 10 173608 pace of ca school employees                             8.73e5 pace o… ## # … with 178,120 more rows

what: Calculate jaccard_similarity of two character vectors — jaccard_similarity
title: Calculate jaccard_similarity of two character vectors — jaccard_similarity
text: Calculate jaccard_similarity two character vectors

title: Calculate jaccard_similarity of two character vectors — jaccard_similarity
code: jaccard_similarity(a, b, ngram_width = 2)

title: Calculate jaccard_similarity of two character vectors — jaccard_similarity
text: first character vector b first character vector ngram_width length shingles / ngrams used similarity calculation

title: Calculate jaccard_similarity of two character vectors — jaccard_similarity
text: vector jaccard similarities strings

title: Calculate jaccard_similarity of two character vectors — jaccard_similarity
code: jaccard_similarity(c("the quick brown fox","jumped over the lazy dog"),     c("the quck bron fx","jumped over hte lazy dog")) #> [1] 0.5714286 0.7692308

what: Spatial Anti Join Using KD-Trees — kd_anti_join
title: Spatial Anti Join Using KD-Trees — kd_anti_join
text: Spatial Anti Join Using KD-Trees

title: Spatial Anti Join Using KD-Trees — kd_anti_join
code: kd_anti_join(a, b, by = NULL, threshold = 1)

title: Spatial Anti Join Using KD-Trees — kd_anti_join
text: first dataframe wish join. b second dataframe wish join. named vector indicating columns join . Format dplyr: = c("column_name_in_df_a" = "column_name_in_df_b"), two columns must specified dataset (x column y column). threshold distance threshold units considered match

title: Spatial Anti Join Using KD-Trees — kd_anti_join
text: tibble fuzzily-joined basis variables . Tries adhere standards dplyr-joins, uses logical joining patterns (.e. inner-join joins keeps observations datasets).

title: Spatial Anti Join Using KD-Trees — kd_anti_join
code: n <- 10  X_1 <- matrix(c(seq(0,1,1/(n-1)), seq(0,1,1/(n-1))), nrow=n) X_2 <- X_1 + .0000001  X_1 <- as.data.frame(X_1) X_2 <- as.data.frame(X_2)  X_1$id_1 <- 1:n X_2$id_2 <- 1:n   kd_anti_join(X_1, X_2, by = c("V1", "V2"), threshold =.00005) #> [1] V1.x V2.x id_1 V1.y V2.y id_2 #> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)

Fuzzy anti-join using minihashing — lsh_anti_join
text: Fuzzy anti-join using minihashing

title: Fuzzy anti-join using minihashing — lsh_anti_join
code: lsh_anti_join(   a,   b,   by = NULL,   block_by = NULL,   n_gram_width = 2,   n_bands = 45,   band_width = 8,   threshold = 0.7,   clean = FALSE )

title: Fuzzy anti-join using minihashing — lsh_anti_join
text: first dataframe wish join. b second dataframe wish join. named vector indicating columns join . Format dplyr: = c("column_name_in_df_a" = "column_name_in_df_b") block_by named vector indicating column block , rows disagree field considered match. Format dplyr: = c("column_name_in_df_a" = "column_name_in_df_b") n_gram_width length n_grams used calculating jaccard similarity. best performance, set large enough chance string specific n_gram low (.e. n_gram_width = 2 3 matching first names, 5 6 matching entire sentences). n_bands number bands used minihash algorithm (default 40). Use conjunction band_width determine performance hashing. default settings (.2,.8,.001,.999)-sensitive hash .e. pairs similarity less .2 >.1% chance compared, pairs similarity greater .8 >99.9% chance compared. band_width length band used minihashing algorithm (default 8) Use conjunction n_bands determine performance hashing. default settings (.2,.8,.001,.999)-sensitive hash .e. pairs similarity less .2 >.1% chance compared, pairs similarity greater .8 >99.9% chance compared. threshold jaccard similarity threshold two strings considered match (default .95). similarity euqal 1 jaccard distance two strings, 1 implies strings identical, similarity zero implies strings completely dissimilar. clean strings fuzzy join cleaned (coerced lower-case, stripped punctuation spaces)? Default FALSE

title: Fuzzy anti-join using minihashing — lsh_anti_join
text: tibble fuzzily-joined basis variables . Tries adhere standards dplyr-joins, uses logical joining patterns (.e. inner-join joins keeps observations datasets).

title: Fuzzy anti-join using minihashing — lsh_anti_join
code: # load baby names data library(babynames)  baby_names <- data.frame(name = tolower(unique(babynames$name))) baby_names_sans_vowels <- data.frame(                 name_wo_vowels =gsub("[aeiouy]","", baby_names$name)    ) # Check the probability two pairs of strings with # similarity .8 will be matched with a band width of 30 # and 30 bands using the `lsh_probability` function: # Run the join: joined_names <- lsh_anti_join(               baby_names,               baby_names_sans_vowels,               by = c("name"= "name_wo_vowels"),               threshold = .8,               n_bands = 20,               band_width = 6,               n_gram_width = 1,               clean = FALSE # default               ) joined_names #> # A tibble: 161,611 × 2 #>    name      name_wo_vowels #>    <chr>     <chr>          #>  1 mary      NA             #>  2 anna      NA             #>  3 emma      NA             #>  4 elizabeth NA             #>  5 minnie    NA             #>  6 margaret  NA             #>  7 ida       NA             #>  8 alice     NA             #>  9 bertha    NA             #> 10 sarah     NA             #> # ℹ 161,601 more rows

title: Plot S-Curve for a LSH with given hyperparameters — lsh_curve
text: n_bands number LSH bands calculated band_width number hashes band

title: Plot S-Curve for a LSH with given hyperparameters — lsh_curve
text: plot showing probability pair proposed match, given Jaccard similarity two items.

title: Plot S-Curve for a LSH with given hyperparameters — lsh_curve
code: # Plot the probability two pairs will be matched as a function of their # jaccard similarity, given the hyperparameters n_bands and band_width. lsh_curve(40,6)

Format dplyr: = c("column_name_in_df_a" = "column_name_in_df_b") block_by named vector indicating column block , rows disagree field considered match. Format dplyr: = c("column_name_in_df_a" = "column_name_in_df_b") n_gram_width length n_grams used calculating jaccard similarity. best performance, set large enough chance string specific n_gram low (.e. n_gram_width = 2 3 matching first names, 5 6 matching entire sentences). n_bands number bands used minihash algorithm (default 40). Use conjunction band_width determine performance hashing. default settings (.2,.8,.001,.999)-sensitive hash .e. pairs similarity less .2 >.1% chance compared, pairs similarity greater .8 >99.9% chance compared. band_width length band used minihashing algorithm (default 8) Use conjunction n_bands determine performance hashing. default settings (.2,.8,.001,.999)-sensitive hash .e. pairs similarity less .2 >.1% chance compared, pairs similarity greater .8 >99.9% chance compared. threshold jaccard similarity threshold two strings considered match (default .95). similarity euqal 1 jaccard distance two strings, 1 implies strings identical, similarity zero implies strings completely dissimilar. ' clean strings fuzzy join cleaned (coerced lower-case, stripped punctuation spaces)? Default FALSE

title: Fuzzy full-join using minihashing — lsh_full_join
text: tibble fuzzily-joined basis variables . Tries adhere standards dplyr-joins, uses logical joining patterns (.e. inner-join joins keeps observations datasets).

title: Fuzzy full-join using minihashing — lsh_full_join
code: # load baby names data library(babynames)  baby_names <- data.frame(name = tolower(unique(babynames$name))) baby_names_sans_vowels <- data.frame(                 name_wo_vowels =gsub("[aeiouy]","", baby_names$name)    ) # Check the probability two pairs of strings with # similarity .8 will be matched with a band width of 30 # and 30 bands using the `lsh_probability` function: lsh_probability(.8,30,8) #> [1] 0.9959518 # Run the join: joined_names <- lsh_full_join(               baby_names,               baby_names_sans_vowels,               by = c("name"= "name_wo_vowels"),               threshold = .8,               n_bands = 20,               band_width = 6,               n_gram_width = 1,               clean = FALSE # default               ) joined_names #> # A tibble: 381,850 × 2 #>    name    name_wo_vowels #>    <chr>   <chr>          #>  1 ld      dl             #>  2 jhamar  jrmh           #>  3 brijin  jbrn           #>  4 mathan  mtthn          #>  5 mehreen nmrh           #>  6 shamarr mrsh           #>  7 stathan ntsh           #>  8 mechell mchll          #>  9 taksh   tksh           #> 10 kshon   nksh           #> # ℹ 381,840 more rows

what: Help Choose the Appropriate LSH Hyperparamaters — lsh_hyper_grid_search
title: Help Choose the Appropriate LSH Hyperparamaters — lsh_hyper_grid_search
text: Runs grid search find hyperparameters achieve (s1,s2,p1,p2)-sensitive locality sensitive hash. locality sensitive hash can called (s1,s2,p1,p2)-sensitive strings similarity less s1 less p1 chance compared, two strings similarity s2 greater p2 chance compared. example, (.1,.7,.001,.999)-sensitive LSH means strings similarity less .1 .1% chance compared, strings .7 similarity 99.9% chance compared.

title: Help Choose the Appropriate LSH Hyperparamaters — lsh_hyper_grid_search
code: lsh_hyper_grid_search(s1 = 0.1, s2 = 0.7, p1 = 0.001, p2 = 0.999)

title: Help Choose the Appropriate LSH Hyperparamaters — lsh_hyper_grid_search
text: s1 s1 paramater (first similaity). s2 s2 parameter (second similarity, must greater s1). p1 p1 paramater (first probability). p2 p2 parameter (second probability, must greater p1).

title: Help Choose the Appropriate LSH Hyperparamaters — lsh_hyper_grid_search
text: named vector hyperparameters meet LSH criteria, reducing runitme.

title: Help Choose the Appropriate LSH Hyperparamaters — lsh_hyper_grid_search
code: # Help me find the parameters that will minimize runtime while ensuring that # two strings with similarity .1 will be compared less than .1% of the time, # strings with .8 similaity will have a 99.95% chance of being compared: lsh_hyper_grid_search(.1,.9,.001,.995) #> band_width    n_bands  #>          4          5

what: Find Probability of Match Based on Similarity — lsh_probability
title: Find Probability of Match Based on Similarity — lsh_probability
text: port lsh_probability function textreuse package, arguments changed reflect hyperparameters package. gives probability two strings jaccard similarity similarity matched, given chosen bandwidth number bands.

title: Find Probability of Match Based on Similarity — lsh_probability
code: lsh_probability(similarity, n_bands, band_width)

title: Find Probability of Match Based on Similarity — lsh_probability
text: similarity similarity two strings want compare n_bands number LSH bands used hashing. band_width number hashes band.

title: Find Probability of Match Based on Similarity — lsh_probability
text: decimal number giving proability two items returned candidate pair minihash algotithm.

title: Find Probability of Match Based on Similarity — lsh_probability
code: # Find the probability two pairs will be matched given they have a jaccard_similarity of .8, # band width of 5, and 50 bands: lsh_probability(.8,5,50) #> [1] 7.136035e-05

what: Fuzzy String Grouping Using Minhashing — lsh_string_group
title: Fuzzy String Grouping Using Minhashing — lsh_string_group
text: Fuzzily groups character vector similar strings assigned group. Uses fastgreedy.community community detection algorithm igraph package create groups. Must igraph installed run properly

title: Fuzzy String Grouping Using Minhashing — lsh_string_group
code: lsh_string_group(   string,   n_gram_width = 2,   n_bands = 45,   band_width = 8,   threshold = 0.7 )

title: Fuzzy String Grouping Using Minhashing — lsh_string_group
text: string character wish perform entity resolution . n_gram_width length n_grams used calculating jaccard similarity. best performance, set large enough chance string specific n_gram low (.e. n_gram_width = 2 3 matching first names, 5 6 matching entire sentences). n_bands number bands used minihash algorithm (default 40). Use conjunction band_width determine performance hashing. default settings (.2,.8,.001,.999)-sensitive hash .e. pairs similarity less .2 >.1% chance compared, pairs similarity greater .8 >99.9% chance compared. band_width length band used minihashing algorithm (default 8) Use conjunction n_bands determine performance hashing. default settings (.2,.8,.001,.999)-sensitive hash .e. pairs similarity less .2 >.1% chance compared, pairs similarity greater .8 >99.9% chance compared. threshold jaccard similarity threshold two strings considered match (default .95). similarity euqal 1 jaccard distance two strings, 1 implies strings identical, similarity zero implies strings completely dissimilar.

title: Fuzzy String Grouping Using Minhashing — lsh_string_group
code: string <- c("beniamino", "jack", "benjamin", "beniamin",     "jacky", "giacomo", "gaicomo") lsh_string_group(string, threshold = .2, n_bands=90) #> [1] "beniamino" "jack"      "beniamino" "beniamino" "jack"      "giacomo"   #> [7] "gaicomo"
